discourse_list.title: [Informal Poll] Should we allow leaked private conversations on the forum?

content.content: In lieu of a guide or playbook to resolve internal conflict, we should at least avoid shooting ourselves in the foot by allowing such behaviour in the forum. Depending on poll results, I would propose at a minimum the removal of leaked private content from the forum. Also if there is support for a system that penalizes flagged content and members that consistently break the forum’s code of conduct we could come up with a framework. The penalties can include a temporary suspension from posting but for now I strongly believe we need to assess if the DAO is also in agreement that posts of screenshots attacking members based on private conversations should not take place here. content.content: Terrible idea. This is a DAO. The only proper place to discuss key topics is on this transparent forum. No one is going to take sharing private chats lightly, since they’ll be shunned from all other chats if they don’t make a compelling point. Also, if someone has evidence from a chat that MKR holders need to see (regarding improper conduct, or even illegal acticity), then they need to feel ok about sharing it transparently and broadly in this forum. Censorship has absolutely no place here.

content.content: In case it helps others think through this (not easy) question, my initial reaction was “not allowed, of course”. But @ChrisBlec’s points make sense. In addition, if someone wants to publish privately-obtained info, they will do it elsewhere anyway. But then regular forum members will be split between those who read the info elsewhere and those who did not, creating an “in-the-know” club, with no easy way for those who don’t follow the right channels to get that info since posting links to them here will also be disallowed (logically). So yeah, no censorship on this, but of course heavy levels of shunning from whoever believes the drastic act of revealing private conversations was not justified.

content.content: TRUEMAKER:  I strongly believe we need to assess if the DAO is also in agreement that posts of screenshots attacking members based on private conversations should not take place here.   I think it’s pretty clear from responses in the other thread (including Will’s own decision to retract the screenshots) that most people agree private conversations should not be leaked on the forum. @ChrisBlec is right that people will not share private chats lightly, but I disagree with him that we should encourage people to “feel OK about sharing [leaks] broadly”. As the other thread shows, leaks don’t tend to drive fact-based debate or thoughtful discussion. They act as a lightning rod for ad hominem arguments and sock puppets piling on. Of course, there should be a process and allowance for whistleblowing if a CU observes illegal/corrupt behaviour, but that’s a pretty high bar, as it should be. Feeling uncomfortable about private confidences being divulged publicly seems like common sense, not censorship.

content.content: Please keep in mind that due to security and legal reasons some conversations should not be shared. Please be mindful that there are people out there that wish to do harm before publishing  anything. It’s a good idea to think twice. Also, I would think twice (maybe think more than twice) about knowingly re-disseminating language that people feel is defamatory, as that re-dissemination can be defamation in many jurisdictions.

content.content: Sharing screenshots of private group chats (whatsapp, discord, telegram, etc) is mostly what I am referring too (this year at least 3 posts have had content like this). It’s very easy nowadays to share a screenshot or short video that was edited just to show only a small part of an entire movie, easily and thoughtlessly. Photos or videos taken out of context are a very strong source of visual misinformation.  Is it really necessary to go that far?  Canceling with ‘hate’ everything that expresses a contrary idea is as reprehensible as the criticized message.  Remember that behind every user there is a human being.

content.content: This is a good observation because even in the law, some places are now recognizing the impact of screen shots. Not that this substantively is the same but New York’s highest court recently held that screenshots are admissible as evidence, so long as the proponent lays the proper foundation. It seems that the issue of screenshots and how they can be used in society is rapidly changing. And, with that change, comes responsibility. People should be mindful of what they say because there are indeed people behind the user (except for the bots )

content.content: There are good reasons to share leaks. If someone admits to a crime or sexually harasses you, then by all means leak those messages. What we could do is set up guidelines for what should be leaked. They don’t need to be binding. Just an overview saying “here is the etiquette for publicly posting private conversations”.

content.content: I think this just goes to show that the Meta-DAO concept is essential.  Maker has become too complex to be run on a single forum/discord with a single set of rules. Ideally this kind of stuff would not percolate up to Maker holders and individual Meta-DAOs would deal with it in house as they see fit.   Until that happens (and Maker isn’t responsible for picking up the pieces when CU’s blow up), censorship is not the solution.

content.content: Some things should be off-limits for forum posts. So if a post with private conversation screenshots are posted without the full context (i.e. edited to show a small portion of the full picture), community members should have the ability to flag and take it down. Another potential option is for posts containing screenshots to trigger a quick review from the GovAlpha (or other team that reviews flagged content) team to confirm with the author that they feel the privacy violation is necessary, that way the content can be assessed and gives the post author a recommendation but ultimately its up to the author to take the recommendation or not. I am not in favor of censorship but I do think we should protect the forum from becoming an unproductive channel. If someone wants to post screenshots there are other channels to do so, Discord or Twitter may be more appropriate, but the forum should be protected from this unnecassary drama. Also, the last two screenshot forum posts have been taken down (the screenshots) by the authors, it shows that its an impulsive decision and after reflection is not the right thing to do.
